In the coordinate plane, the graph of
\[|x + y - 1| + \Big| |x| - x \Big| + \Big| |x - 1| + x - 1 \Big| = 0\]is a certain curve.  Find the length of this curve.
inference:
Since the length of the graph of a piecewise-smooth function
$$f(x) \text{ on } [a, b]$$

is
$$\int_a^b \sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx} \right)^2} dx \quad \text{or} \quad \int_a^b \sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dx}{dy} \right)^2} dy$$

we apply this result here.  First we compute
$$\begin{split}\frac{dy}{dx} & = \frac{\frac{\partial}{\partial x} [x + y - 1] |x + y - 1|^{-1} + \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \big[ |x| - x \big] \big[ |x| - x \big]^{-1} + \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \big[ |x - 1| + x - 1 \big] \big[ |x - 1| + x-1 \big]^{-1}}{\frac{\partial}{\partial y} [x + y - 1] |x + y - 1|^{-1} + \frac{\partial}{\partial y} \big[ |x| - x \big] \big[ |x| - x \big]^{-1} + \frac{\partial}{\partial y} \big[ |x - 1| + x - 1 \big] \big[ |x - 1| + x-1 \big]^{-1}} \\\ & = \frac{|x + y - 1|^{-1} + \frac{x}{|x|} |x|^{-1} - 1 \cdot |x|^{-1} + |x-1|^{-1} + \frac{x}{|x-1|} |x-1|^{-1} - 1 \cdot |x-1|^{-1}}{|x + y - 1|^{-1} + 0 + 0}\end{split}$$

Since 
$$|x + y - 1|^{-1} = \begin{cases} 1, & x + y - 1 \ge 0  \\\ -1, & x + y - 1 < 0 \end{cases} \quad \text{and} \quad |x|^{-1} = \begin{cases} 1, & x \ge 0  \\\ -1, & x < 0 \end{cases}$$

and
$$|x - 1|^{-1} = \begin{cases} 1, & x - 1 \ge 0  \\\ -1, & x - 1 < 0 \end{cases} $$

we see that
$$\begin{split} \frac{dy}{dx} & = \frac{|x + y - 1|^{-1} + \frac{x}{|x|} |x|^{-1} - 1 \cdot |x|^{-1} + |x-1|^{-1} + \frac{x}{|x-1|} |x-1|^{-1} - 1 \cdot |x-1|^{-1}}{|x + y - 1|^{-1} + 0 + 0} \\\ & = \begin{cases} \frac{2}{|x + y - 1|}, & x + y \ge 1 \text{ and } x \ge 0  \\\ \frac{-2}{|x + y -1|}, & x + y \ge 1 \text{ and } x < 0 \\\ \frac{2}{|x|}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x \ge 0  \\\ \frac{-2}{|x|}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x < 0  \\\ \frac{2}{|x-1|}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x-1 \ge 0  \\\ \frac{-2}{|x-1|}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x-1 < 0 \end{cases}  \end{split}$$

So 
$$\begin{split}\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx} \right)^2} & = \begin{cases} \sqrt{1 + \frac{4}{|x + y -1|^2}}, & x + y \ge 1 \text{ and } x \ge 0  \\\ \sqrt{1 + \frac{4}{|x + y -1|^2}}, & x + y \ge 1 \text{ and } x < 0 \\\ \sqrt{1 + \frac{4}{|x|^2}}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x \ge 0  \\\ \sqrt{1 + \frac{4}{|x|^2}}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x < 0  \\\ \sqrt{1 + \frac{4}{|x-1|^2}}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x-1 \ge 0  \\\ \sqrt{1 + \frac{4}{|x-1|^2}}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x-1 < 0 \end{cases}  \\\ & = \begin{cases} \frac{\sqrt{|x + y -1|^2 + 4}}{|x + y -1|}, & x + y \ge 1 \text{ and } x \ge 0  \\\ \frac{\sqrt{|x + y -1|^2 + 4}}{|x + y -1|}, & x + y \ge 1 \text{ and } x < 0 \\\ \frac{\sqrt{|x|^2 + 4}}{|x|}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x \ge 0  \\\ \frac{\sqrt{|x|^2 + 4}}{|x|}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x < 0  \\\ \frac{\sqrt{|x-1|^2 + 4}}{|x-1|}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x-1 \ge 0  \\\ \frac{\sqrt{|x-1|^2 + 4}}{|x-1|}, & x + y < 1 \text{ and } x-1 < 0 \end{cases} \end{split}$$

Thus
$$\begin{split}\text{Length} & = \int_{-\infty}^\infty \sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx} \right)^2} dx \\\ & = \int_{-\infty}^0 \frac{\sqrt{|x|^2 + 4}}{|x|} dx + \int_0^1 \frac{\sqrt{|x-1|^2 + 4}}{|x-1|} dx + \int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{|x + y -1|^2 + 4}}{|x + y -1|} dx \\\ & = \int_0^\infty \frac{\sqrt{x^2 + 4}}{x} dx + \int_1^0 \frac{\sqrt{(x-1)^2 + 4}}{x-1} (-dx) + \int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{(x + y -1)^2 + 4}}{x + y -1} dx \\\ & = \int_0^\infty \frac{\sqrt{x^2 + 4}}{x} dx + \int_0^1 \frac{\sqrt{x^2 + 4}}{x} dx + \int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{(x + y -1)^2 + 4}}{x + y -1} dx \\\ & = \int_0^\infty \frac{\sqrt{x^2 + 4}}{x} dx + \int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{(x + y -1)^2 + 4}}{x + y -1} dx \\\ & = \left[ 2\sqrt{x^2 + 4} \right]_0^\infty +  \left[ 2\sqrt{(x + y -1)^2 + 4} \right]_1^\infty \\\ & = 4\end{split}$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{4}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
The only way that the sum of absolute terms can be 0 is if each absolute value term is equal to 0.  Thus,
\begin{align*}
|x + y - 1| &= 0, \\
\Big| |x| - x \Big| &= 0, \\
\Big| |x - 1| + x - 1 \Big| &= 0.
\end{align*}From the second equation, $|x| - x = 0,$ or $|x| = x.$  Thus, $x$ must satisfy $x \ge 0.$

From the third equation, $|x - 1| + x - 1 = 0,$ or $|x - 1| = 1 - x.$  Thus, $x$ must satisfy $1 - x \ge 0,$ or $x \le 1.$

Finally, from the first equation, $x + y = 1.$  Thus, the graph is the line segment joining $(0,1)$ and $(1,0)$.  The length of this line segment is $\boxed{\sqrt{2}}.$
